Award.AwardTitle: MRI: Acquisition of an Analytical Transmission Electron Microscope (TEM) with High Resolution for Multi-disciplinary Research and Training
Award.AbstractNarration:
An award is made to South Dakota State University (SDSU) to acquire a state-of-the-art, high resolution, analytical, transmission electron microscope (TEM). The TEM will be housed in a shared facility to enable and encourage interdisciplinary collaboration of faculty and students from colleges and universities across South Dakota and the region. The TEM will be incorporated into SDSU outreach activities to help high school science teachers stimulate student interest in pursuing careers in science, technology, engineering, and math.

The TEM will allow researchers to examine many different materials on the molecular level and nano-scale, which will immediately benefit a broad research portfolio. The TEM will be used in several projects to aid energy independence including developing better photovoltaic materials, developing better electrochemical energy storage devices, and developing better catalysts for converting biomass to gasoline. The TEM will also be used in projects to increase sustainable food production by allowing researchers to focus in on the mechanics of emerging viral infectious diseases and examining the resource exchange processes in mycorrhizal-plant interactions.

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.DRECONTENT:
The TEM JEM 2100 has been installed and used for characterizing more than hudreds different materials samples from multiple collaborators in different department at SDSU. The TEM has been used to help developing a new room temperature plasma process for preparing graphene for energy storage in supercapacitor, as well as enable developing multiple innovative renewable carbon materials for energy storage, volatile chemicals recovery in water purification and biofuel production, and blood purification. 4 graduates and one technician have been trained for operating the TEM system and related maintenance. More than 17 undergraduates from different university gained experience of using the TEM for materials characterization as well as leaning how advanced analysis technology enable research of sustainable agriculture, catalysts of advanced biofuel production, water purification and biosensing. The TEM funded by NSF fund has inspired collaboration among different departments, and resulted more than external $450,000 funding of multiple projects related to sustainable agriculture, (biochar application and impact, drainage water and fertilizer recycling), and microbial fuel cell, from USDA-NIFA, Sungrant (North Central) and NASA EpsCor. programs. The TEM system will continous inspire inter-discipline collaboration of research and education activities in SDSU, as well as enable more collaboration with local partners, such as Sanford Healthcare and Avera Healthcare.

 


Last Modified: 11/06/2017
Modified by: Zhengrong Gu
